text: mark thanks so much for joining me today
sure thanks for having me mark can you
put these latest attacks in some
perspective for us in terms of their
severity is there a sign that that
they're escalating now as the
announcement has been made about the
date of the election well even by Iraq
standards these this was a bad day and
these were a series very powerful and
severe bombings you've had a number of
other big bombings in recent months in
October and in August in particular and
all of them striking at institutions
that really are important to the basic
functioning of the state so this fits
into that pattern I think as we get
closer to the elections the fear was
always that the militants would try and
step up attacks and that's part of the
reason why the American military
withdrawal was scheduled around those
elections what does this say and I
assume it's nothing very good about the
ability of the Iraqi security forces to
protect Baghdad well it really
undermines the public confidence in the
security forces I mean you have to
remember this is still a fortress city
with checkpoints on every street corner
blast walls lining neighborhoods and
still militants are able to carry out
attacks like this coordinated and
devastating strikes so it undermines
public confidence and also you have a
political campaign going on where
different political parties want to cast
blame on the other so in Parliament
which held a session after these
bombings you didn't have one politician
stand up and defend the security forces
what's your what does this feel like out
in the city what how are people reacting
are they feeling I assume an increasing
level of frustration over this or can
you describe the mood there when we went
out to a couple of these bomb scenes
ourselves today and it was really
striking how just how quickly the mood
in the city can shift it it felt like a
wartime footing again I've been coming
here since 2003 and it really had the
mood of a city on it with some
expectation I assume there's some
expectation that these kinds of attacks
might increase as as the Rockies get
closer and closer to an election is
there you have any sense tonight or what
more steps the security forces might
take to try and secure
or the city better than a house so far
well given the political finger-pointing
that's already going on there there is a
tension within the Baghdad ministries
and who has control over the security
apparatus I think part of part of the
problem here is that these these
agencies don't always work together so I
think you'll see calls for them to work
together but so I'm not sure you'll see
much dramatic in the way of a change
although you might see a name replaced
here and there then again you know I
wouldn't want to predict anything to
Shirley about Iraq mark I know it's been
a long day for you thank you so much for
your time thank you Jim
